Award.AbstractNarration:
Plants respond to touch stimulation such as the wind, rain or the brushing by of animals by switching on a series of responses that make them sturdier and more resistant to damage. This research seeks to discover the genes that allow plants to trigger these responses. Results from this research will help define how plants defend themselves against environmental stresses with potential practical applications in the breeding or engineering of more resistant crops. The work will also involve the training of postdoctoral researchers, graduate students and undergraduate students in plant science. The program will help promote an understanding of plant research to the general public thorough a series of presentations and practical demonstrations.

Despite its key role in determining their form and function, the molecular machinery underlying plant mechanical sensing and response remains very poorly defined. In addition, the mechanisms behind the known crosstalk between the mechanical and defense response systems remains largely uncharacterized. Changes in cytoplasmic Ca2+ are known to be some of the earliest signals generated by both mechanical stimuli and defense elicitors. This research program therefore seeks to define the role of the Ca2+-responsive calmodulin and calmodulin-like gene families in these processes. Bioinformatics will first be used to define the calmodulin and calmodulin-like protein-related mechanical response network. Analysis of gene expression, plant development, Ca2+ dynamics and pathogen sensitivity in mutants in these network genes will then be made to test their functional roles in touch and pathogen responses. These analyses will help to define the roles of these network elements in: (1) mechanical signaling and, (2) the crosstalk between mechanical and defense responses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research has aimed at defining the plant molecular networks that allow the cellular signaling triggered in response to mechanical stimulation (touch) to communicate with the networks that underlie how plants defend themselves against pathogens.

To pursue the mechanical stimulation element of this work, a computer numeric control- (CNC-) based robot was developed that draws a plastic stimulation sheet across the growing plants. The duration, interval and speed of the stimulation are all programmable, allowing for application of the highly reproducible mechanical stimulation needed for touch-based assays. This equipment was designed and built in collaboration with an undergraduate in the University of Wisconsin?s engineering program and this undergraduate has used this and other experiences in practical problem-solving challenges in engineering to start his own consulting business. This robot has allowed for the following of the effects of touch on growth and development as well as patterns of gene expression that touch triggers. It has helped reveal a tradeoff between continued plant growth and the production of elevated defenses in the plant. I.e., touch stimulated plants are better defended against herbivores and pathogens but grow more slowly. Touch stimulation by factors such as the weather or animals passing by are constant features of the environment that plants grow in and so this work suggests that these growth versus defense tradeoffs are likely to be a common, integral element controlling how plants develop.

A further major finding from the work has been that a network of genes related to cellular calcium signaling that are activated by touch also play a role in pathogen defense. These genes belong to the calmodulin and calmodulin-like families and plants where these genes are mutated to be inactive show loss of touch responses, such as the stunting of plant growth that usually accompanies mechanical stress to the plant. Most, but not all, of these mutants were also compromised in their ability to defend against bacterial pathogen attack. These results suggest that at a practical level it may be possible to use manipulation of the touch responses in the plant to also alter its pathogen defenses.

This project also revealed a rapid calcium-related signaling system triggered by wounding stress. Wounding a leaf triggers release of chemical messengers that then in turn trigger a mobile wave of cellular response that moves throughout the plant. The wave is characterized by increases in cellular calcium levels that act as signals to trigger defense responses. These waves can move at millimeters per second and require the activity of cellular receptors of a family of proteins called the glutamate receptor-like channels. The chemical signal that is released upon wounding to trigger the system appears to be the amino acid glutamate that is likely binding to the channels to activate them.

As part of this work, two graduate students both successfully completed their Ph.D.s, focusing on research related to the role of cellular calcium pumps in mediating defense against bacterial pathogens and on the calcium signaling network triggered by both touch and pathogen stimuli. Undergraduates working on the project have gone on to pursue graduate school in the plant sciences at institutions such as Stanford and Washington University in St Louis, to pursue medical school and to start their own business. This research was also used as the basis of outreach events to both school students and the general public at venues ranging from the University of Wisconsin's 'Science Saturdays' to events such as the local winter enrichment lecture series at Madison's arboretum and talks to societies such as the Milwaukee chapter of the American Society for Metals.
